data.title: Robin Hauser - Finish Line Features
data.meta_description: Experience: Finish Line Features ¬∑ Location: Park City ¬∑ 500+ connections on LinkedIn. View Robin Hauser‚Äôs profile on LinkedIn, a professional community of 1 billion members.
data.text:
Today, we have the remarkable Debra Cohen. From her days as a New Wave rocker in Boston, opening for Joan Jett, to studying the Bible in Israel and converting to Judaism, Debra's journey is full of bold moves and resilience. Overcoming childhood trauma and addiction, Debra reinvented herself as a DIY indie artist and producer, and recently, as an author. Her book, "Jewish Palestine/Arab Palestine: A History of Conflict," aims to shed light on the complex history of the region. Debra's path also includes being a former ESOL teacher, Postmaster, aromatherapist, and full-time RVer. She met her husband at 62 and now tackles post-Covid fitness challenges, proving it's never too late to pursue your passions. Discussion Topics: Journey to Becoming an Entrepreneur: Debra shares her path to entrepreneurship, highlighting her diverse experiences and what inspired her to take bold steps in her career. Influence of Music and Creativity: How Debra‚Äôs experiences as a New Wave rocker influenced her current work as a DIY indie artist. The inspiration behind her book and what she hopes readers will gain from it. Balancing Health and Creativity: How Debra maintains her physical and mental health while pursuing her creative passions. Practical tips for integrating self-care into a busy entrepreneurial life. Personal and Professional Journey: Debra discusses how her personal journey has shaped her entrepreneurial path and her approach to work. The importance of community support in her life as an indie artist and author. Strategies for Motivation and Inspiration: Techniques Debra uses to stay motivated and inspired. Handling financial uncertainties and pressures as an indie artist and author. Yoga and Wellness: The role of yoga and meditation in managing entrepreneurial stress. Tips for older adults dealing with sedentary lifestyles, obesity, and aging. Challenges and Misconceptions: Overcoming significant challenges in her career. Addressing common misconceptions about being an entrepreneur in creative fields. Future Projects and Goals: Debra‚Äôs future projects and plans for continuing her evolution as a creative entrepreneur. Setting goals and measuring success in her entrepreneurial journey. Key Takeaways: The importance of balancing creative pursuits with physical and mental health. Practical tips for maintaining motivation and handling the stresses of entrepreneurship. The role of community and support systems in achieving entrepreneurial success. How personal journeys and diverse experiences can shape and enhance entrepreneurial paths.

The New York Times has long been seen as a bastion of American journalism, with nearly 10 million readers putting their trust in the Gray Lady to deliver all the news that's fit to print. However, in recent years trans readers and journalists alike have raised concerns about the Times' pattern of coverage on the transgender community. This culminated in February 2023, when thousands of readers and contributors co-signed a letter outlining these concerns; alongside them, GLAAD and numerous other organizations did the same in a separate letter. The New York Times responded by not only dismissing these concerns, but subsequently publishing a defense of author J.K. Rowling, a vocal opponent of transgender rights. In the year that followed, myself and a talented team of folks at Media Matters explored the paper's news coverage of anti-transgender legislation in order to lay some hard figures down on the table. The results were damning: ‚û° 66% of the articles did not quote even one trans or gender-nonconforming person. ‚û° 18% of the articles quoted misinformation from anti-trans activists without adequate fact-checking or additional context. ‚û° 6 articles obscured the anti-trans background of sources, erasing histories of extremist rhetoric or actions. If transgender people are to be free from the throes of this one-sided culture war, our news media must be willing to uphold a standard of ethical coverage to better inform our citizens. If The New York Times cannot set that example, the failures will only trickle down from there. You can read our report here: https://lnkd.in/eJi2KCtD
